claim.statement: Price subsidies on artemisinin combination therapies (ACTs) substantially increase access to treatment but worsen targeting, resulting in high levels of overtreatment—particularly among adults—while the addition of rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs) raises testing rates yet does not immediately eliminate overtreatment.
claim.statement_location: Abstract and Introduction (pages 1–3) of the original paper PDF

data.source: Field experiment data combining administrative drug-shop transaction records, surprise rapid diagnostic tests, and baseline/endline household surveys
data.wave_or_subset: Single experimental wave covering first illness episode reported during the study period
data.access_details: Primary data collected by research team; no public access details stated
data.notes: Administrative purchase data were matched to household survey responses; surprise RDTs provided objective malaria status for a large share (≈93%) of ACT purchasers.

method.description: The study randomly assigned households in Western Kenya to receive vouchers for varying ACT subsidy levels (80%, 88%, 92%) with or without subsidised rapid diagnostic tests (RDTs). Researchers tracked medicine purchases through participating drug shops, conducted surprise RDTs to determine malaria status, and administered baseline and endline surveys to measure treatment-seeking behaviour, access, and targeting outcomes.
steps: Identify and recruit four rural drug shops willing to honour vouchers.
Enumerate 2,789 households living in the shops’ catchment areas and conduct a baseline survey.
Randomly assign households to one of the following groups: (a) no subsidy, (b) ACT subsidy only (80%, 88%, or 92%), (c) ACT + RDT subsidy (various RDT price/refund combinations).
Distribute paper vouchers indicating the assigned subsidy level(s).
Monitor drug-shop transactions, recording each ACT and RDT sale as well as patient age and symptoms.
Implement surprise RDT offers to ACT purchasers to establish actual malaria positivity.
Conduct an endline survey capturing all illness episodes and treatments during the study window.

Analyse impacts of subsidy level and RDT availability on (i) ACT access, (ii) targeting (share of ACTs taken by malaria-positive patients), (iii) treatment-seeking locations, and (iv) costs and welfare.
method.models: OLS and logistic regressions estimating treatment effects on access (A) and targeting (T), controlling for household and patient characteristics with standard errors clustered at the household level; additional cost-effectiveness and welfare calculations.
method.outcome_variable: Primary: ACT take-up (binary) and targeting (malaria-positive share among ACT takers); Secondary: malaria testing rate, drug-shop visit, antibiotic use, cost per correctly treated case.
method.independent_variables: Randomly assigned ACT subsidy level (80%, 88%, 92%), presence and price of RDT subsidy, interaction terms between ACT and RDT subsidies.
method.control_variables: Patient age group, household demographics, baseline distance to drug shop and health facility, illness severity indicators.

results.summary: A 92% ACT subsidy more than doubled ACT use (41% vs. 19% in control) but only 56% of subsidised ACTs went to malaria-positive patients, indicating poor targeting. Reducing the subsidy to 80% preserved high access while increasing targeting to 75%. RDT subsidies (≥85%) doubled the testing rate, yet about half of malaria-negative patients still purchased ACTs, so short-run targeting gains were limited. Overall, modestly lower ACT subsidies offered a more cost-effective balance between access and accurate targeting than the very high AMFm-style subsidy.

numerical_results.effect_size: Decrease of ~0.24 relative to perfect targeting (1.0)

numerical_results.outcome_name: Malaria testing rate with RDT subsidy (≥85%)
numerical_results.effect_size: Increase of ~0.21 compared to no RDT offer
